body.p: One of the reasonable criticisms of rehabilitation research is that it is often difficult to know what treatment intervention was actually given. Nowhere is this more true than for ‘cognitive rehabilitation’ (see http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09602011.2012.6808911). This issue includes two new studies of cognitive rehabilitation where interventions are described, hopefully in sufficient detail to allow replication. One on people with memory problems includes people with a mixture of neurological disorders, which helps generalisation. Conversely, the other focuses on a single disorder, but a variety of cognitive deficits. The intervention is also described specifically in photographs in a trial comparing two taping techniques for people with back pain, in which there was a minor symptomatic difference only. Whole body vibration is another easily described treatment, and is compared with exercise as a treatment to improve function in frail older people in a trial where it seemed to have a short-term functional benefit. In contrast, the neurodevelopmental or Bobath treatment approach has always been difficult to describe and in a randomised controlled trial in this issue it is compared with a metronome as a way of altering gait pattern; it was found that the differences are small. Neuromuscular stimulation is another treatment that is, or should be, easy to describe and a systematic review managed to obtain descriptions for the studies included – but there was considerable variation in the parameters used and no firm conclusion can be drawn about its use for people with osteo-arthritis of the knee. Another problem for systematic reviewers is the variety of measures of outcome used, and perhaps some reduction will occur in studies of osteoarthritis of the knee or hip following a comparative study of six measures. However, further studies should continue to compare measures. Recent concerns about the introduction of technologically-based treatments (prosthetic hips) without adequate research can be mirrored for technological measures, and a systematic review on the use of ultrasound to measure muscle size shows that there is little evidence of reliability. Last but not least, a study on podiatry and foot care in rheumatoid arthritis shows that we pay little attention to feet despite their obvious importance.
